subject: Languages
title: British Sign Language: Same Country, Different Language
description: A quick, practical guide to British Sign Language: Same Country, Different Language.

hook.text: British Sign Language and American Sign Language are so different that their users can barely communicate.

buildup.text: BSL developed independently in Britain from at least the 1570s, centuries before ASL existed.

discovery.text: BSL uses a two-handed fingerspelling alphabet. ASL uses a one-handed one. Even basics differ.

twist.text: BSL was only officially recognized as a language by the UK government in 2003.

climax.text: In 2022, the BSL Act made it a legally recognized language of England, Wales, and Scotland.

punchline.text: It took Britain 450 years to legally admit its deaf citizens have their own language.

quiz.question: When was BSL officially recognized as a language in the UK?
